10.1016/S1872-2067(24)60110-5 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Reusability of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (Ru = 0.5 wt%, Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0.4 wt%) catalyst in 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis. Details were described in Table S4. Reaction conditions: 1,2-BuD = 0.5 g, H2O = 4 g, m cat = 0.2 g, P(H2) = 8 MPa, T = 453 K, t = 24 h. a Reuse method 1: after reaction, the catalyst was collected by centrifugation (6000 r min‐1, 5 min), washed with water and dried at 383 K for 12 h. b Reuse method 2: after reaction, the catalyst was collected by centrifugation (6000 r min‐1, 5 min), washed with water, dried at 383 K for 12 h, and then calcined at 573 K for 1 h. Fig. 2 Time course of 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (Ru = 0.5 wt%, Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0.4 wt%) catalyst. Details were described in Table S5. Reaction conditions: 1,2-BuD = 0.5 g, H2O = 4 g, m cat = 0.2 g, P(H2) = 8 MPa, T = 453 K. Fig. 3 XRD patterns (30o−50o) of monometallic catalysts and Ru(y)-Ir-Fe/BN (Ru = y (0−3) wt%, Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0 or 0.4 wt%) catalysts after reaction. (a) FeO x /BN (Fe = 0.4 wt%); (b) Ir/BN; (c) Ru(0.5)/BN; (d) Ir-Fe/BN; (e) Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN; (f) Ru(0.3)-Ir-Fe/BN; (g) Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN; (h) Ru(1.5)-Ir-Fe/BN; (i) Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN; (j) BN. Reaction conditions: 1,2-BuD = 0.5 g, H2O = 4 g, m cat = 0.2 g, P(H2) = 8 MPa, T = 453 K, t = 24 h. a The crystallite size was calculated based on the Ru metal at about 44o (fitting result was shown in Fig. S3), and the size of Ir species was not calculated due to the low intensity. XRD patterns (30°−75°) of catalysts are provided in Fig. S2. Fig. 4 TEM-EDX analysis of used catalysts (Ru = 0.5 wt% or 3 wt%, Ir = 0 or 5 wt%, Fe = 0 or 0.4 wt%). (A, A′) Ru(0.5)/BN; (B, B″) Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN; (C, C″) Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN; (D, D″) Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN. Reaction conditions: 1,2-BuD = 0.5 g, H2O = 4 g, m cat = 0.2 g, P(H2) = 8 MPa, T = 453 K, t = 24 h. Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of monometallic catalysts and Ru(y)-Ir-Fe/BN (Ru = y (0−3) wt%, Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0 or 0.4 wt%) catalysts. (a) Ru(0.5)/BN; (b) Ir/BN; (c) Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN; (d) Ir-Fe/BN; (e) Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN; (f) Ru(1.5)-Ir-Fe/BN; (g) Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN. Fig. 6 DRIFT spectra of CO adsorbed on catalysts (Ru = 0−3 wt%, Ir = 0 or 5 wt%, Fe = 0 or 0.4 wt%) after reduction at 473 K for 1 h. n.d.: no data. Y-axis is normalized by corresponding CO adsorption amount except Ru/BN catalysts. a Dispersion (%) determined by the molar ratio of chemisorbed CO to total noble metal; measured after reduction under a H2 flow at 473 K for 1 h in a gas phase (see Table 4). Fig. 7 Proposed structure of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst during reaction and possible mechanisms. Note: the partial covering of the alloy particles with BN may occur, especially in the dry catalyst. Available online 20 October 2024 Article Promoting role of Ru species on Ir-Fe/BN catalyst in 1,2-diols hydrogenolysis to secondary alcohols Ben Liu a † Yoshinao Nakagawa a b * Mizuho Yabushita a b Keiichi Tomishige a b c * a Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Tohoku University, 6-6-07 Aoba, Aramaki, Aoba-ku, Sendai, 980-8579, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry School of Engineering Tohoku University 6-6-07 Aoba Aramaki Aoba-ku Sendai 980-8579 Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Tohoku University, 6-6-07 Aoba, Aramaki, Aoba-ku, Sendai, 980-8579, Japan b Research Center for Rare Metal and Green Innovation, Tohoku University, 468-1, Aoba, Aramaki, Aoba-ku, Sendai, 980-0845, Japan Research Center for Rare Metal and Green Innovation Tohoku University 468-1 Aoba Aramaki Aoba-ku Sendai 980-0845 Japan Research Center for Rare Metal and Green Innovation, Tohoku University, 468-1, Aoba, Aramaki, Aoba-ku, Sendai, 980-0845, Japan c Advanced Institute for Materials Research (WPI-AIMR), Tohoku University, Katahira 2-1-1, Aoba-ku, Sendai, 980-8577, Japan Advanced Institute for Materials Research (WPI-AIMR) Tohoku University Katahira 2-1-1 Aoba-ku Sendai 980-8577 Japan Advanced Institute for Materials Research (WPI-AIMR), Tohoku University, Katahira 2-1-1, Aoba-ku, Sendai, 980-8577, Japan * Corresponding author † Present address: Department of Chemistry, Fudan University, Shanghai 200433, China Noble metal-based-bimetallic catalysts have been highly investigated and applied in wide applications including biomass transformation via regioselective C−O hydrogenolysis while further modification especially with noble metal is highly promising yet still under investigation. Herein, Ru was found as an effective modifier among the screened noble metals (Ru, Pt, Rh, Pd, Au, and Ag) for Ir-Fe/BN (Ir = 5 wt%, Fe/Ir = 0.25) catalyst in terminal C−O hydrogenolysis of 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BuD) to 2-butanol (2-BuOH). Only trace amount of Ru (up to 0.5 wt%) was effective in terms of high 2-BuOH selectivity (> 60%) and activity (about twice). Larger amount of Ru species (3 wt%) highly enhanced the activity but gave low selectivity to 2-BuOH with by-products of terminal C−C bond scission. Optimized catalyst (Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN) was reusable at least 4 times and gave moderate 2-BuOH yield (47%) in hydrogenolysis of 1,2-BuD. The promoting effect of Ru addition (0.5 wt%) to Ir-Fe/BN on hydrogenolysis of various alcohols was also confirmed. Combining catalytic tests with various characterizations, the promotion mechanism of Ru species in trimetallic catalysts was clarified. The Ru species in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN form alloy with Ir and are enriched at the interface with BN surface, and direct interaction between Ru and Fe was not necessary in Ru-Ir-Fe alloy. The interface of Ir and Fe on the surface of Ir-Fe alloy may work as active sites for 1,2-diols to secondary alcohols via direct C−O hydrogenolysis, in which Ru-modified Ir activates H2 to form hydride-like species. The activity of Ru species in C−C bond cleavage was highly suppressed due to the direct interaction with Ir species and less exposed to substrate. Larger loading amount of Ru species (3 wt%) led to the formation Ru-rich trimetallic alloy, which further works as active sites for C−C bond scission. Graphical Abstract The addition of a trace amount of Ru (0.5 wt%) to the Ir-Fe/BN catalyst results in the formation of a Ru-Ir alloy enriched at the interface of the BN surface. This alloy effectively activates H2, leading to a significant enhancement (~2-fold) in the activity of terminal C−O hydrogenolysis, while maintaining a high level of selectivity. Keywords Biomass-based polyols Secondary alcohol Hydrodeoxygenation Trimetallic alloy Boron nitride 1 Introduction Biomass, a sustainable and carbon-neutral candidate to produce chemicals and fuels via biomass refinery, has attracted huge and increasing attentions due to the depletion of traditional fossil resources and the increasing pressure of global warming [1–4]. Most biomass-derived building blocks (such as sugar alcohols (glycerol, erythritol, xylitol etc.)) proposed for biomass refinery contain a number of C−O bonds [5–7]. Oxygenates are promising target value-added chemicals derived from such building blocks. Therefore, the development of catalysts with various regioselectivity to enable the scission of specific C−O bond(s) is necessary for extending the scope of biomass-derived chemicals and fuels. Noble metal-based bimetallic catalysts have been widely investigated and already exhibited wide applications including biomass transformation [8,9]. M-ReO x (M = Ir and Rh) [10–13] and Pt-WO x catalysts [14,15] have been developed and widely applied in 1,2-diols hydrogenolysis to primary alcohol, for example, glycerol to 1,3-propanediol. The removal of both OH groups of 1,2-diols (e.g. erythritol to 1,2-butanediol) over the ReO x -M (M = Pd, Ag and Au) or the mixture catalysts (ReO x /CeO2 and pre-reduced Ni/CeO2) was achieved via the route of deoxydehydration and hydrogenation [16–21]. On the other hand, selective removal of primary OH group of 1,2-diols to produce secondary alcohols is not highly focused or investigated; however, such regioselectivity is highly attractive in terms of extending the scope of biomass-derived chemicals, for example, erythritol to 2,3-butanediols [22,23]. Importantly, C−O hydrogenolysis of terminal OH groups seems like a missing piece of united hydrodeoxygenation system containing above-mentioned regioselectivity patterns, where synthesizing all corresponding C3-C6 alcohols from biomass-derived platforms such as glycerol, erythritol, xylitol and sorbitol is possible. Therefore, development of regioselectivity pattern of 1,2-diols to secondary alcohols is meaningful and important. Ir-Fe catalysts were recently found to be effective for 1,2-diol hydrogenolysis to secondary alcohol [24,25]. Ir-Fe/BN was reusable due to the strong interaction between supported metals and support, where the interface of Ir-Fe alloy was clarified as possible active sites [26]. However, the activity of bimetallic Ir-Fe catalysts was quite low (about two orders lower than the activity of Ir-Re catalysts for 1,2-diol hydrogenolysis to primary alcohol even at much higher reaction temperature (453 vs. 393 K)), and the selectivity was not excellent (about 70% to 2-butanol from 1,2-butanediol). For hydrogenolysis reactions, in general, the activity increase is essential in practical view because of the high price of noble metal and large capital cost [27]. Further modifications are typically necessary and useful for noble metal-based catalysts in terms of enhancing catalytic performance (activity/selectivity/stability). Various means such as addition of transition metals (especially noble metals) have been widely reported as an effective strategy for such objective in a variety of reactions, e.g., hydrogenation, hydrogen generation and electrocatalysis [28–31]. The addition of noble metals typically contributes to the promotion of H2 dissociation and adjustment of electronic/geometric properties of active phases, which are vital for improving the catalytic performance, in particular activity. In other words, trimetallic catalyst, an emerging area in the advancement of catalyst-based process, could be a possible strategy, while compositions, morphology, and dimensions play a key role in the catalytic performance [31]. The addition of noble metal (e.g., Ru, Pd, Rh, and Au) into metal-metal oxide type catalyst (e.g., Ir-ReO x and Pt-WO x ) has been reported as an effective strategy [32–37]. Ru-added Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst exhibited higher activity (conversion: 2−3 times) in glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-propanediol than the case of Ir-ReO x /SiO2 [32]. The separate existence of Ir-ReO x and Ru-ReO x was clarified, where the increase of active species on Ir-ReO x (active sites) by spillover of H species on Ru-ReO x (promoting sites) contributed to high activity. The addition of Pd to Ir-ReO x /SiO2 was effective in furfural to 1,5-pentanediol via hydrogenation + hydrogenolysis, where the Pd-ReO x and Ir-ReO x species work as active sites, respectively [33]. Trimetallic Pd-Ir-ReO x /SiO2 was also tested for hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 1,6-hexanediol; however, double-layer catalysts consisting of Pd/SiO2 and Ir-ReO x /SiO2 gave better results [38]. By contrast, the formation of Ir-Rh alloy modified with ReO x was clarified as key factor of improving activity in the same reaction over Rh-Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst [34]. Pt modified Ir-ReO x /SiO2 exhibited improving activity in the catalytic conversion of sorbitol to gasoline-ranged products than Ir-ReO x /SiO2, and the synergetic effect of Pt, Ir and ReO x species (active structure: Pt-Ir alloy modified with ReO x ) is important [39]. Au was reported as a modifier for Pt-WO x /Al2O3 [40] and Pt/WO x [35,37] to improve the catalytic activity for glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,3-propanediol, and the Au was present as highly dispersed species on Pt or WO x . These reports showed that modification with additional noble metal can improve the performance of bimetallic catalysts, especially activity, while various structures can be constructed depending on the combination. On the other hand, the selectivity is sometimes decreased by the modification because the complication of structures may produce active sites for undesirable side reactions [32]. As for the case of recently developed Ir-Fe/support (support = rutile and BN) catalysts exhibiting the unique regioselectivity pattern but low activity, the addition of noble metal may pave the way to improving the activity. Selective construction of multi-metallic sites and further clarification of structure-activity relationship are quite difficult and still few in examples, but worth investigating to develop highly efficient catalysts for wide range of hydroprocessing reactions [31,41]. Therefore, C−O hydrogenolysis of primary OH group(s) over NM-Ir-Fe/BN (NM: noble metal) was selected as a model of biomass transformation over trimetallic catalysts containing two noble metals. Besides, we note that the addition of non-noble Mo species to Ir-Fe/BN catalyst effectively enhanced the activity (up to ~25-fold) by the formation of Ir-Fe-Mo trimetallic alloy phase, which was very recently reported [42]; however, the promotional effect of Mo is very specific to this combination because oxophilic Mo is exceptionally easily reduced to the metallic state on this support (BN). In this study, further modification with another noble metal on noble metal-based-bimetallic alloy (Ir-Fe/BN) was found an effective strategy for improving the activity of 1,2-butanediol hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol while maintaining the high selectivity to the secondary alcohol. Previously reported works on 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis are summarized in Table S1. Ru was found as an effective modifier for Ir-Fe/BN catalyst among the screened noble metals (Ru, Pt, Rh, Pd, Au and Ag). The addition of trace amount (0.5 wt%) Ru could almost effectively doubled the activity with similar regioselectivity, where the ability of C−C bond dissociation of Ru species was mainly suppressed. Higher loading of Ru species rather tended to dissociate C−C bond, while the activity was further improved. The structure of optimized catalysts and the interaction and cooperation of trimetallic metals (Ru, Ir and Fe) were clarified by combining with catalytic tests and various characterizations. In particular, Ir-Ru (Ir-rich) alloy is mainly formed on BN and works as vital roles in enhancing the catalytic performance. In contrast, the formation of Ir-Ru alloy under mild conditions is not easy, while carbon was normally reported as effective support for Ir-Ru alloy mainly as electrocatalysis [43,44]. Limited reports on Ir-Ru alloy in thermo-catalysis are summarized in Table S2, where harsh reduction conditions are normally necessary and insights into the role of metals during reactions are still expected. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation M(y)-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts (M = Ru, Pt, Rh, Pd, Au and Ag; y: the loading amount of M (0−3 wt%); Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0.4 wt% (Fe/Ir = 0.25)) were prepared by a co-impregnation method as follows. BN (crystal structure: h-BN, BET specific surface area: 5.8 m2 g−1) was firstly impregnated with a solution containing precursors. After drying at 383 K for 12 h, the sample was then calcined at 773 K for 3 h. The metal precursors of optimized Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst are RuNO(NO3)3, H2IrCl6 and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, respectively. Other bimetallic and monometallic catalysts were prepared via the same procedure. Details of chemicals used are described in Table S3. 2.2 Activity tests and product analysis The activity test was conducted in a stainless-steel autoclave (190 mL) with an inner glass vessel. Typically, water (4 g), catalyst (0.2 g), and substrate (0.5 g) were added into the inner vessel. Then, 1 MPa H2 was used to vent air three times, and after that, 5 MPa H2 was introduced during heating process. Once the temperature reached at 453 K, 8 MPa H2 was introduced, and this time was defined as 0 h of reaction time. Products in gas phase and that in a liquid phase except C4 polyols were quantified with a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2025) equipped with an Rtx-1 PONA capillary column (diameter 0.25 mm, 100 m) and FID. Highly functionalized compounds were analyzed by a high-performance liquid chromatograph (HPLC; Shimadzu Prominence system) with a refractive index detector and a UV-vis detector. The HPLC conditions were as follows: Aminex HPX-87H column (ø7.8 × 300 mm), mobile phase = 0.01 mol L−1 H2SO4 at 0.5 mL min−1, temperature = 313 K. The conversion, selectivity and carbon balance were calculated using the following equations: Conversion (%) = (1 – (sum of C-based mol of residual substrate)/(sum of C-based mol of products and residual substrate)) × 100; Selectivity (%) = ((C-based mol of product)/(sum of C-based mol of products)) × 100; Carbon balance (C.B., %) = {(sum of C-based mol of products and residual substrate)/(C-based mol of loaded substrate)} × 100. Average conversion rate (AR) = (loaded substrate (mmol) × conversion/(t (h) × m Ir (g))). 2.3 Catalyst characterizations For X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples, Rigaku MiniFlex600 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation) was used. The average metal particle size was calculated based on the Scherrer equation. Typically, the width of the peak at about 41° derived from the Ir (111) lattice plane was used for calculation. A Titan3™ 60−300 (FEI-Company) equipped with an EDS (super X) was used to collect the transmission electron microscope (TEM) images and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyses of catalysts. Typically, the used catalysts were collected and dried at 383 K for 12 h for TEM-EDX analysis. The size of primary particles in the supported dendritic material was determined by measuring the local maximums of width of the string. According to the HR-TEM image, the connection between primary particles tended to be formed at the longer ends of the ellipsoids, and thus we call the determined size as “shorter length.” Average particle size (short length) was calculated by Σnidi 3/Σnidi 2 (di : particle size; ni : number of particles with size di ). For the temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) measurements, a homemade fixed-bed reaction system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a frozen acetone trap was used. Typically, the fresh samples (0.05 g) were heated in 5% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) at a rate of 10 K min−1 from room temperature to 1100 K. As for FT-IR spectra of adsorbed CO (CO-DRIFT), a Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer equipped with an in-situ cell and mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector was used. The sample was pre-reduced in the cell with H2 (473 K, 1 h) and then the CO adsorption and DRIFT measurement were carried out at room temperature. For CO chemisorption measurement, a catalyst analyzer BELCAT II (MicrotracMRB) connected to a quadrupole mass spectrometer (MicrotracMRB; BELMASS) was used. Typically, the samples were pre-reduced with H2 in gas phase (473 K, 1 h) and then CO pulses were introduced at 323 K. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on the Shimadzu AXIS-ULTRA DLD spectrometer under high vacuum at ambient temperature. The binding energy was calibrated with a C 1s peak of sample-loaded adhesive tape at 284.6 eV. The samples were pre-reduced under the liquid-phase conditions (water, 8 MPa H2, 453 K, 1 h). The pre-reduced samples were separated and dried in the glovebox filled with Ar, and finally, they were transferred to the measurement chamber without exposure to air. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were carried out at the BL14B2 station at SPring-8, approved by the Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute (JASRI) (Proposal No. 2022B1746). The data for Ir L 3-edge were recorded in the transmission mode, while the fluorescence mode was used for that of Ru K-edge (except Ru3-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst (the transmission mode)) and Fe K-edge measurements. The sample preparation was conducted in N2 atmosphere: the used catalysts were collected and transferred into a plastic sample bag under N2 atmosphere and measured without exposure to air atmosphere. For the fresh catalyst, the preparation process was carried out in air atmosphere. The storage ring was operated at 8 GeV, and a monochromatic X-ray beam was obtained by using a Si (111) single crystal. The detector (ion chamber) for I 0 was filled with 100% N2 for Ir L 3-edge, Ru K-edge and Fe K-edge measurements. The detector for I 1 was filled with 80% N2 + 20% Ar for Ir L 3-edge, Ru K-edge and Fe K-edge measurements. For analysis, the extracted oscillation was obtained using a spline smoothing approach from the original EXAFS data. The empirical phase shift and amplitude functions for the Ir–O and Ir–Ir bonds were extracted from the data of IrO2 and Ir powder, respectively. The empirical phase shift and amplitude functions for the Ru–O and Ru–Ru bonds were extracted from the data of RuO2 and Ru powder, respectively. Theoretical curves for the Fe–Ir, Fe–Ru, Fe–Fe, Fe–O, Ir–Fe, Ir–Ru, Ru–Fe, Ru−B, Ru−N, and Ru–Ir were calculated with the FEFF 8.20 program. Normally, analyses of XANES and EXAFS data were performed using a computer program (REX2000, ver. 2.6; Rigaku Corp.). The Athena and Artemis software were used for LCF analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The effect of addition of second noble metal (Ru, Pt, Rh, Pd, Au and Ag) on the 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BuD) hydrogenolysis over Ir-Fe/BN (Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0.4 wt%; optimized Fe/Ir ratio in bimetallic catalysts [26]) was investigated (Table 1 ). Small amount of Ru species (0.5 wt%) was effective for enhancing the activity (conversion: 14.6% → 25.7%) and preserving high 2-butanol (2-BuOH) selectivity (68.8% → 62.3%), while the other screened modifiers (Pt, Rh, Pd, Au and Ag) with the same loading amount (0.5 wt%) were less effective (Table 1, entries 3−9). As for monometallic catalysts (Ir/BN, FeO x /BN and Ru0.5/BN), only Ru(0.5)/BN exhibited high activity (conversion: 41.5%) with a low 2-butanol/1-butanol (2-BuOH/1-BuOH) ratio (1.7), and C−C scission products were mainly obtained (selectivity of alkanes (<C4) + 1-propanol (1-PrOH) = ~85%). It has been known that monometallic Ru catalysts have activity in the C−C scission of polyols and alkanes [45–48]. In contrast, the selectivity of C−C scission products in 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN was not high (alkanes (<C4) + 1-PrOH = ~16%), which means that the high C−C scission activity of Ru species was much inhibited. The addition of second metal (Pd, Pt or Cu) to Ru/TiO2 was also reported to suppress the C−C hydrogenolysis activity of Ru species in glycerol hydrogenolysis, while the structure of catalyst was not clearly defined [49, 50]. Bimetallic catalysts (Ru(0.5)-Fe/BN and Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN) were further prepared as control catalysts. The addition of small amount of Fe (0.4 wt%) species significantly deactivated the Ru(0.5)/BN catalyst. Fe species was previously reported as a poison for Ir-ReO x /SiO2 [51]. Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN exhibited much lower activity (conversion: 3.1% vs. 41.5%) than Ru(0.5)/BN catalyst, while the 2-BuOH selectivity was highly improved by the combination with Ir (37.1% vs. 5.3%). Therefore, both Fe and Ir decreased the activity of undesirable function of Ru in C−C scission. On the other hand, the physical mixture of Ru(0.5)/BN (0.2 g) and Ir-Fe/BN (0.2 g) gave a high conversion (35.3%) similar to Ru(0.5)/BN, and 2-BuOH selectivity (42.0%) was highly improved but lower than Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (62.3%). The decreasing selectivity to alkanes (< C4) and 1-PrOH (85% → 37%) of the physical mixture suggested that the C−C scission activity of Ru(0.5)/BN was partly suppressed by the presence of Ir-Fe/BN. This phenomenon may be interpreted by the re-distribution of metals of the physical mixture during the reaction similar to the previously reported case of ReO x /CeO2 + Ni/CeO2 [17], where the interaction between Ni and Re species was formed during reaction and highly affected the catalytic behavior. The aforementioned results suggested that the synergistic effect between Ru, Ir and Fe species plays a vital role in the catalytic performance. The loading amount of Ru, as the only effective modifier among the screened noble metals at 0.5 wt%, was further optimized for Ru-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts (Table 2 ). The activity of catalyst increased with a similar regioselectivity pattern until the amount of Ru species reached 0.5 wt%. Further addition of Ru species (Ru = 0.5% → 3 wt%) led to a clear decrease of 2-BuOH selectivity (62.3% → < 40%, at < 30% conversion level), while the activity was highly enhanced (conversion: 25.7% → 95.3%). Similar enhanced activity was reported in the case of Ru-added Ir-ReO x /SiO2 catalyst (Ru = 4.4 wt%, glycerol conversion: 9.4% → 44.6%) [32], while the selectivity loss by Ru addition to Ir-Fe/BN was less significant than that to Ir-ReO x /SiO2. The possible structure-activity relationships are different and will be clarified in the following part. The decrease of 2-BuOH selectivity at higher Ru loading than 0.5 wt% was due to the formation of C-C scission products such as 1-PrOH. Very small amount of Ru (0.5 wt%) seems optimal in terms of high 2-BuOH selectivity and activity. In addition, based on this dependence on Ru amount, the performances of Ru-Ir-Fe/BN and other M-Ir-Fe/BN can be compared at the same molar ratio. The 0.5 wt% loading of Pt, Rh, Pd, Au and Ag corresponds to the Ru loading of 0.26 wt%, 0.49 wt%, 0.48 wt%, 0.26 wt% and 0.47 wt%, respectively, as the same mole of M. Based on the results of Entries 2‐4 of Table 2, the Ru-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts have higher activity than the other M(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts at the same molar ratio, again confirming Ru as the best additive. Furthermore, the increase of the loading amount of metals with constant relative compositions (0.5 wt% → 2 wt% Ru, 5 wt% → 20 wt% Ir, 0.4 wt% → 1.4 wt% Fe) (Table 2, Entry 6) less affected the catalytic performance of Ru-Ir-Fe/BN, while the addition of Mo to Ir-Fe/BN was reported to drastically improve the activity when the loading amount was large [42]. The promotional effect of Ru works well for both catalysts with low and high metal loading. The reusability of catalyst, as one of the well-known challenges for biomass conversion catalysis [52,53], was investigated (Fig. 1 and Table S4). In the case of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN, an obvious decrease of activity (25.7% → 14.6%) was observed in the second run when the catalyst was only dried after the first run (method 1: 383 K, 12 h), while the 2-BuOH selectivity remained high (> 60%); no further deactivation was observed in the subsequent reuse. As suggested by TG-DTA (Fig. S1), carbonaceous species deposited on the surface of catalyst were removed at about 503 K, which may be related to the deactivation during the reuse experiments. Therefore, in Method 2, the additional step of calcination (573 K, 1 h) was added to Method 1, which is enough to remove surface-deposited species. With Method 2, higher activity (~1.3 times) with similar regioselectivity than that of fresh case was observed even after the 4 times use, which suggested that the deposited carbonaceous species may mainly account for the deactivation in the case of reuse Method 1. A slight increase of activity (~1.4 times) has been also observed in the reuse experiments of Ir-Fe/BN, which may be interpreted by exposing more active sites [26]. The increase of exposing active sites of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst during the reuse experiments was further confirmed in the section of characterization (vide infra). These results demonstrated the good reusability of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN similar to that of Ir-Fe/BN, where a suitable regeneration method was important. The time course of 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN was also investigated (Fig. 2 and Table S5). The 2-BuOH selectivity slightly decreased from 62% to 54% with extending reaction time. The yield of 2-BuOH reached 47% at 86% conversion, which is slightly lower than the previous cases (Ir-Fe/rutile TiO2, Ir-Fe/BN and Ir-Fe-Mo/BN (64%)); high 2-BuOH selectivity (> 60%) was kept even at a very high conversion level (>90%) [24,25,42]. The average conversion rate (AR, mmol gIr ‐1 h‐1) was also compared both at initial stage (conversion < 30%; Ir-Fe/rutile TiO2 (2.0) < Ir-Fe/BN (3.4) < Ru-Ir-Fe/BN (5.9) < Ir-Fe-Mo/BN(83.5)) and high conversion level (conversion > 85%; Ir-Fe/BN (0.2) < Ir-Fe/rutile TiO2 (0.3) < Ru-Ir-Fe/BN (5.0) < Ir-Fe-Mo/BN (34.6)). Considering the very high activity of Ir-Fe-Mo/BN (>20-fold activity increase compared to Ir-Fe/BN), Ir-Fe-Mo/BN is superior to Ru-Ir-Fe/BN. The selectivity to n-butane and ≤ C3 products gradually increased in Fig. 2. The formation of these by-products from 2-BuOH occurred probably over Ru sites. The effect of Ru addition (0.5 wt%) to Ir-Fe/BN (Ir = 5 wt%, Fe = 0.4 wt%) on hydrogenolysis of related alcohols was further investigated (Tables 3 and S6: the similar trends to the case of 1,2-BuD were observed. C3 (1,2-propanediol and glycerol) and C4 (1,3-BuD and erythritol) alcohols hydrogenolysis over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst exhibited higher activity and similar selectivity to secondary alcohols, compared to the case of Ir-Fe/BN. These data demonstrated the improving effect of Ru species on Ir-Fe/BN catalyst in related alcohols including 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis. Besides, the formation of 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PrD) from glycerol, 1,2,4-butanediol (1,2,4-BuT) from erythritol were slightly promoted over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst than that case of Ir-Fe/BN catalyst, which was not observed in the case of Mo-modified Ir-Fe/BN catalyst [42]. In contrast, threitol formation was suppressed by the addition of Ru (threitol selectivity: 24% (Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN) vs. 34% (Ir-Fe/BN)), where similar suppression phenomenon was also confirmed with the addition of Mo species to Ir-Fe/BN catalyst [42]. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The effect of Ru addition on the microstructural properties of supported metals in used catalysts was initially investigated by XRD (Fig. 3 (30°−50°) and Fig. S2 (30°−75°)). Signals related to BN were detected as the main peaks. No obvious peak related to oxide state of supported metals (Ru, Ir, and Fe) was observed. The peak of Ir metal located at about 41° was detected in Ir/BN (Ir = 5 wt%), which was sensitive to the addition of other species (Ru and/or Fe). A slight shift to higher angle in Ir-Fe/BN suggested the formation of Ir-Fe alloy with fcc-structure [26], while no obvious shift was observed in the case of Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN. The formation of Ru-Ir alloy remained unclear from the XRD pattern because of the similar atomic radii of Ru and Ir. For trimetallic catalysts, the peak at about 41° remained as the main signal until the amount of Ru addition up to 0.5 wt%, indicating that the main metallic phase was still fcc. On the other hand, the signal of hcp-type metallic phase was detected in Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts (Ru = 3 wt%) similar to Ru-added Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (Ru = 4.4 wt%) [32], which suggested that the further addition of Ru species caused the structural phase change from fcc to hcp (Fig. S3). Considering the relatively large amount of Ru species (Ru = 3 wt%), the formation of Ru-rich species is possible, which may account for the increasing C−C dissociation activity. The crystallite size of supported metals was calculated to be about 2−3 nm regardless of the loading amount of Ru species, although these sizes could be underestimated because of the heterogeneity in the composition. Furthermore, small crystallite size (2−4 nm) of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN after reuse was also confirmed (Fig. S4 and Table 4 ), agreeing with its high stability. In contrast, large Ir(Ru)O2 particles (12 nm) were mainly present in the fresh catalyst before reaction. Similar rutile-Ir(Ru)O2 signals were mainly detected in the fresh Ir-involved catalysts (Fig. S5). Rutile-RuO2 signals can be clearly observed in the fresh Ru/BN catalyst (Fig. S5). These results demonstrated the in-situ reduction of supported relatively large metal oxide particles (10−12 nm) into small metallic crystallites (2−3 nm), similar to previous report on Ir-Fe/BN [26]. The addition of Ru species less affected such in-situ reduction process of supported metals on Ir-Fe/BN. TEM was used to investigate the morphology and distribution of supported metals in the Ru-added catalysts (Figs. 4 and S6). As reported in our previous research, both Ir/BN and Ir-Fe/BN catalysts consist of two dimensional nanodendrites (2−3 nm) preferentially located at the edges of BN, which has been interpreted by the strong interactions between Ir and edges of BN [26]. Two-dimensional nanodendrites (~3 nm) with similarly distributed metals were observed in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (Figs. 4(C) and S6), which suggested the formation of trimetallic phase with strong interaction between components in line with the XRD result. HR-TEM was further used to obtain more information of Ru species (Figs. S7 (images of various catalysts) and S8 (images in various resolutions for Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN)). The crystalline nature of the metallic nanodendrites was confirmed. It is difficult to clearly distinguish single atom Ru species from noise, while such presence cannot be excluded. The Ru species in Ru(0.5)/BN was more aggregated than the case of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (Figs. 4(A) and S7(A)). The presence of Ir species promoted the dispersion of Ru species, probably via the formation of Ir-Ru alloy. Further increasing the loading amount of Ru species less affected both the size (~3 nm) and the distribution of supported metals. The formation of Ru-rich metallic particles on Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst was possible. The strong interaction of supported metals regardless of the loading amount of Ru species was confirmed, which is in line with the XRD and H2-TPR results. XANES analyses were conducted to determine the valence state of supported metals in the fresh (denoted as “calcination”) and used catalysts (denoted as “react”) (Figs. S9, S10). The XANES spectra (Ru K-edge, Fe K-edge, and Ir L 3-edge) of used Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN and related catalysts were similar to those of corresponding metallic samples (Ru powder, Ir powder, and Fe foil), while the spectrum of fresh Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (calcination) more resembled the oxide references. These results suggested that most supported species in used catalysts were reduced during reaction regardless of types of metals or loading amount of Ru species, which suggested the formation of trimetallic alloy. The fitting of the XANES spectra with spectra of metal and oxides (for Ru and Fe) and the white line analysis (for Ir) also confirmed the almost total reduction of each species in used catalysts (Figs. S9 and S10; summary is also shown in Table 4). EXAFS was further carried out to clarify the interactions between supported metals in catalysts. The summary of curve fitting results is shown in Table 5 , and the detailed spectra and curve fitting are provided in the Supplementary Material (Fig. S11 and Table S7: Ru K-edge; Fig. S12 and Table S8: Fe K-edge; Fig. S13 and Table S9: Ir L 3-edge). First, we focus on the Ru K-edge spectra. For Ru(0.5)/BN (react), a Ru−Ru bond (0.268 nm) with CN of about 10 was obtained in the curve fitting, agreeing with the formation of Ru metal particles. In Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN (react) and Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (react), the main metallic bond was Ru−Ir (CN ~7), suggesting the formation of Ir-Ru alloy. Another point is that there was significant contribution of Ru−X (X: light atoms). Considering the almost complete reduction of Ru in both catalysts, we assigned the contribution to Ru−B bonds. Combining with the results of XPS (the quite lower Ru/Ir ratio on the surface), the presence of Ru-rich interface with BN at the bottom of Ru-Ir-Fe crystallites is possible. The formation of metal boride was also proposed in Ir-Fe-Mo/BN (Mo−B) [42]. The Ru−B bonds can exist in Ru(0.5)/BN, but the determination of coordination number is difficult because of the presence of Ru−O bonds. The bond distance of Ru−B in the used catalysts is similar to the case of ruthenium borides (both ~0.22 nm) [54]. The coordination states of Ru species in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (react) were similar to those of Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN (react), which suggested that the existence of small amount Fe species (0.4 wt%) less affected the interaction between Ru and Ir species. For Ru-rich Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN (react, Ru = 3 wt%), the spectrum was fitted with Ru−Ru (CN: 6.2, 0.266 nm), Ru−Fe (CN: 0.4, 0.260 nm) and Ru−Ir bonds (CN: 4.0, 0.268 nm), which suggested the formation of Ru-rich-trimetallic alloy with direct interactions among Ru, Ir and Fe species. The contribution of Ru−B bond was not confirmed in this Ru-rich catalyst. In contrast, the Ru coordination state in Ru(4.4)-Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (Ru = 4.4 wt%, Ir = 4 wt%, Re/Ir = 2) is quite different, where the Ru−Ir bond was totally absent and no direct interaction between Ir and Ru was proposed [32]. Considering the possible presence of Ru−B bond in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN, the bimetallic Ru-Ir particles can be more easily formed on Ru/BN than on SiO2. The Fe K-edge is considered next. The spectrum of Ir-Fe/BN (react, prepared by co-impregnation method) was well fitted with the Fe−Ir (CN: 5.7, 0.262 nm) and Fe−O (CN: 0.4, 0.189 nm) bonds, which suggested the formation of Ir-Fe alloy similar to our previous report [26]. Similar fitting result was achieved in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN (react), suggesting the similar coordination condition of Fe species, which in line with the results of XANES and Ru K-edge EXAFS. In Ru-rich Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN (react), Fe−Fe (CN: 0.8, 0.255 nm) and Fe−Ru (CN: 1.9, 0.260 nm) bonds were present, which agreed with the XANES and Ru K-edge EXAFS results that trimetallic alloy phase was formed. For Ir L 3-edge EXAFS spectra, all used catalysts except Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN (react) can be fitted only with Ir−Ir bond, while the fitting results with Ru−Ir and/or Fe−Ir bonds, whose presence was suggested from the Ru K-edge and Fe K-edge EXAFS (vide supra) (Tables S6−S8), are more reliable. The sum of CNs of metallic Ir−M bonds was in the range of 8.6-9.5, agreeing with the formation of metal nanoparticles. The spectrum of Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN was fitted with Ir−Ir, Ir−Ru and Ir−Fe bonds (CN: 4.1, 4.4 and 0.9, respectively). These fitting results of Ir L 3-edge EXAFS spectra of used catalysts agreed with the results of Ru K-edge and Fe K-edge that all the supported species were reduced to the metallic state and formed alloy, although the composition of the alloy particles may not be homogeneous. The reducibility of Ru-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts was further investigated by H2-TPR (Fig. 5 ), and the corresponding H2 consumption amount was calculated and shown in Table S10. Ru(0.5)/BN catalyst exhibited a reduction peak (400−550 K) with a H2 consumption amount ~0.08 mmol gcat −1, which corresponds to the complete reduction of RuO2. A reduction peak at relatively wider temperature range (350−600 K) was observed for Ir/BN, which was less effected by the further addition of Ru and/or Fe species. As for the FeO x /BN, the reduction peak was located at higher temperature range (700−100 K) [26]. The only reduction peak in the cases of bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts suggested the co-reduction of supported metals. It is difficult to fully reduce the supported metals of catalysts at the reaction temperature (453 K) based on the result of H2-TPR, while the peak of metallic phases in the used catalysts was clearly detected by XRD. The harsh reaction condition (H2O, 8 MPa H2, 453 K) should account for the in-situ reduction process similar to previous cases of Ru-ReO x [24] and Ir-Fe [25]. The H2 consumption amount of Ir/BN was higher than the nominal value, which suggested the progress of BN reduction similar to previous case of Ir/BN (the reduction of support (BN) consumed additional H2) [55,56]. Further addition of small amount Fe and/or Ru species led to the actual consumption amount of H2 close to the nominal value. Less information related to the valence of metals in bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts can be obtained due to the involvement of BN reduction. The effect of Ru addition on the surface state of Ir species was investigated via the DRIFT of adsorbed CO (Fig. 6 ). The samples were reduced with H2 in a gas phase at 473 K, and there might be some differences in the surface state between the active catalyst in the reaction conditions and the samples for CO adsorption because of the difference in the reduction methods (gas phase or liquid phase). Nominally, the signals of linear CO adsorbed on Ru0 located at ~2040 cm−1 [57–59]. Monometallic Ru(0.5)/BN exhibited no adsorption, which may be caused by the trace loading amount (0.5 wt%) of Ru species. Therefore, Ru(3)/BN with larger Ru loading (3 wt%) was further prepared and tested, while this material still did not exhibit any CO adsorption peak. This result suggested that Ru species in Ru/BN were probably covered with support similar to previously-reported Ru-based catalysts [60]. Typically, the linear CO adsorbed on Ir0 species can give signals between 2066 and 2069 cm−1 [12]. A signal centered at 2083 cm−1 was observed on Ir/BN, which was related to the linear adsorption of CO on partially oxidized Ir species [61–63]. A peak with a slight shift to higher wavenumber of Ru(0.5)-Ir/BN than Ir/BN suggested the decreasing electronic density of surface Ir species. The broad signals (1900−2085 cm−1) detected on Ir-Fe/BN may indicate the co-existence of CO adsorbed on Ir0 and Fe0 species, and the presence of broad signals (1900−2050 cm−1) of CO adsorbed on Fe0 species was also reported in the case of Fe/support (support: Al2O3 and SiO2) [64]. The small amount of Ru species (0.5 wt%) obviously decreased the shoulder at around 2000 cm−1 on Ir-Fe/BN, and the higher loading of Ru species exhibited the same behavior. These results suggested that the electronic state of catalyst is sensitive to even small amount of Ru species, which agrees well with the results of 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis (small addition of Ru species doubled the activity with similar regioselectivity pattern). Surface properties were less affected by the structural phase change caused by the further addition of Ru species (fcc→hcp). The CO adsorption amount on the reduced catalysts was also measured and summarized in Table 4. In previous report on Ir-Fe/BN [26], the value of D CO (CO/Ir) was quite lower than the D XRD value, which was interpreted by the possible coverage of metal surface with support. Noble metal (Ir, Pt, Au, Rh, and Ru) encapsulated by overlayers (oxidized boron derived from BN support) has been previously reported [65,66]. Similar trend was observed in Ru-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts and reference catalysts. Therefore, a similar coverage of supported metal surface with BN in Ru-Ir-Fe/BN was possible, which can account for such low CO adsorption. One point should be noted that the D CO value of used Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN was higher than that of fresh catalyst (8% vs. 5%). This result suggested that more active sites were exposing in the case of the spent catalyst, which should be related to the higher activity of used catalyst in the reuse experiments (vide supra) similar to the case of Ir-Fe/BN [26]. XPS was tentatively used to investigate the electronic state of supported metals of catalysts (Fig. S14 and Table 4), while obtaining such information is not easy due to the trace loading amount of metals (e.g., Ru = 0.5 wt%, Fe = 0.4 wt%). A liquid-phase reduction (water, 453 K, 8 MPa H2, 1 h) was used as a pre-treatment for collecting actual information of the active sites during reaction. The peak positions of Ru 3d 5/2 and Ir 4f 7/2 signals were 280.0−280.1 and 60.6−61.0 eV, respectively, for all samples (Ir/BN, Ru-Ir/BN, Ir-Fe/BN, and Ru-Ir-Fe/BN). Although accurate determination of peak position was difficult for Fe 2p signals, the main signal of Fe 2p 3/2 was located around 707−708 eV for both Ir-Fe/BN and Ru-Ir-Fe/BN. The position was within the range of Ru0 3d 5/2 (~280 eV) [67], Ir0 4f 7/2 (~60.7 eV) [68–70], and Fe0 2p 3/2 (~707 eV) [71], suggesting that the supported metals were mainly reduced to the metallic state under the reaction conditions [67–69,72]. No obvious shift was observed on the binding energy of pure Ir0 and Ru0 on BN support than on typical SiO2 support [67–70]. The slightly higher binding energies of Ir 4f in the bimetallic/trimetallic catalysts than that of Ir/BN suggested the decrease of electron density of Ir metal in the presence of Ru and/or Fe species, which suggested the interaction between these additional supported metals with Ir species. The surface composition of catalysts was also calculated and summarized in Table 4. The Ru and Fe contents on the surface of the catalysts are lower and higher than the nominal values, respectively. These results indicate an enrichment of Ru species within the crystallites of supported metals, contrasting with the enrichment of Fe species observed outside the crystallites [42]. Based on the aforementioned characterizations, we proposed possible model structure of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst during reaction (Fig. 7 ). For Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN, two-dimensional-trimetallic alloy with a fcc structure was formed, where the Ru and Fe species separately co-modified Ir nanodendrites: Ru species at the bottom part of crystallites of supported metals, contrasting with the enrichment of Fe species outside the crystallites, based on XPS and the possible presence of Ru−B bonds. The surface of Ir-Fe alloy may behave as active sites for 1,2-diol hydrogenolysis, while the Ir-Ru alloy may work as the promoting sites. Possibly, such Ru species at the bottom of crystallites are effective modifiers. For Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN, Ru-rich trimetallic alloy with a hcp structure was possibly formed. The Ru-rich alloy surface should account for the high activity of C−C bond cleavage, while the remaining Ir-Fe alloy surface may be related to the high ratio of 2-BuOH/1-BuOH (12) in 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis. The structure of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN is quite different with that of Ru(4.4)-Ir-ReO x /SiO2 (Ru = 4.4 wt%, Ir = 4 wt%, Re/Ir = 2) [32], where the separate location of Ru-ReO x and Ir-ReO x species in the absence of any interactions between Ru and Ir species. The strong interaction between Ir and Re(O x ) as well as the strong interaction between metallic Ru and BN support may account for such structure difference. The difference in the behavior of selectivity change by Ru addition between Ir-Fe/BN and Ir-ReO x /SiO2 can be also explained by the structure difference: Ru-Ir-ReO x /SiO2 is less selective than Ir-ReO x /SiO2 because of the presence of Ru-ReO x species with low selectivity, while the selectivity of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN is similar to Ir-Fe/BN because of the very few Ru atoms on the alloy surface. 3.3 Reaction mechanism The effect of H2 pressure on 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN was investigated (Fig. S15 and Table S11). The reaction order with respect to H2 pressure of 0.9 was obtained for both catalysts. The reaction order close to 1 suggested that typical hydride + proton activation mechanism is also involved for the Ir-Fe/BN and Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalysts. The effect of reaction temperature on 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis over Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN and Ir-Fe/BN catalysts was further investigated (Fig. S16 and Table S12). The activity of catalysts was increased with the increase of reaction temperature (T = 393‐453 K), while the selectivity to 2-BuOH remained high (> 60%). The apparent activation energy (E a) was calculated to be 97 and 88 kJ mol‐1 for the Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN and Ir-Fe/BN catalysts, respectively. The addition of Ru species has less effect on the E a value of Ir-Fe/BN catalyst (preparation method: the sequential impregnation method) than the addition of Mo (81.7 → 67.1 kJ mol‐1) [42], which suggested that the Ru species probably only work as promoters for H2 activation rather than as active sites that directly participate in the reaction. Here, we add the possible mechanism of 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis to Fig. 7 describing the proposed catalyst structure. In previous report, the Ir-Fe alloy surface was proposed as possible active sites for 1,2-diols to secondary alcohols [26]. 1,2-BuD was adsorbed on the surface of Ir-Fe alloy via both OH groups and underwent the nucleophilic attack of the hydride at the sterically unhindered terminal OH group, the latter of which was proposed as the rate-determining step. The similar selectivity of Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN to that of Ir-Fe/BN was possibly derived from the similar Ir-Fe alloy active sites, where small amount of Ru species (0.5 wt%) inside the alloy phase were probably involved as a promoter to increase the concentration (occupancy) of surface hydrogen species on the active Ir-Fe sites. If significant Ru atoms are present on the surface of alloy phase (Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN), such species becomes the active site for side reactions, namely C-C dissociation reactions. While there are many mechanisms for metal-catalyzed C-C dissociation, the most probable one in this case is the combination of dehydrogenation and decarbonylation [73] because the main C-C dissociation products were 1-propanol and methane (1,2-butanediol → 2-hydroxybutanal → 1-propanol + CO → 1-propanol + methane). 4 Conclusions The addition of small amount of Ru species (0.5 wt%) effectively doubled the activity of 1,2-BuD hydrogenolysis over Ir-Fe/BN catalyst, while the regioselectivity pattern was similar. The ability of C-C cleavage of Ru species was highly suppressed. The other screened noble metals (Pt, Rh, Pd, Au, and Ag) had less effect on the activity of Ir-Fe/BN catalyst. Larger loading amount of Ru species led to the enhancing activity of terminal C−C bond cleavage. Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN catalyst was reusable at least 4 times when a suitable calcination (573 K, 1 h) was applied as a regeneration treatment similar to the previous case of Ir-Fe/BN. 2-BuOH yield of 47 wt% was obtained, which was slightly lower than Ir-Fe/BN and more active Ir-Fe-Mo/BN catalysts. The similar trend (increasing activity) for the Ir-Fe/BN catalyst by the Ru addition was also confirmed in hydrogenolysis of various alcohols. The characterizations demonstrated the interactions between supported metals which can play a vital role for the catalytic performance. The Ru species in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN form alloy with Ir and are enriched at the interface with BN surface, and they have less effect on the coordination of Ir-Fe alloy. The interface of Ir and Fe on the surface of Ir-Fe alloy may work as active sites for 1,2-diols to secondary alcohol via direct C−O hydrogenolysis, in which Ru-modified Ir activates H2 to form hydride-like species. The activity of Ru species in C−C bond cleavage was highly suppressed due to the direct interaction with Ir species and less exposure to substrate. Larger loading amount of Ru species (0.5 wt% → 3 wt%) led to the formation of Ru-rich trimetallic alloy exposed to substrate, which might account for increasing activity in C−C bond cleavage. The high ratio value of 2-BuOH/1-BuOH over Ru(3)-Ir-Fe/BN was interpreted by the remaining Ir-Fe surface. This study provides insights into noble-metal-modifiers in noble-metal-based-trimetallic catalysts in C−O hydrogenolysis of primary OH groups. The cooperation of three elements in the trimetallic alloy may open the door to the development of highly efficient catalysts in the field sustainable catalysis, especially hydroprocessing reactions. coredata.dc:description: Noble metal-based-bimetallic catalysts have been highly investigated and applied in wide applications including biomass transformation via regioselective C−O hydrogenolysis while further modification especially with noble metal is highly promising yet still under investigation. Herein, Ru was found as an effective modifier among the screened noble metals (Ru, Pt, Rh, Pd, Au, and Ag) for Ir-Fe/BN (Ir = 5 wt%, Fe/Ir = 0.25) catalyst in terminal C−O hydrogenolysis of 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BuD) to 2-butanol (2-BuOH). Only trace amount of Ru (up to 0.5 wt%) was effective in terms of high 2-BuOH selectivity (> 60%) and activity (about twice). Larger amount of Ru species (3 wt%) highly enhanced the activity but gave low selectivity to 2-BuOH with by-products of terminal C−C bond scission. Optimized catalyst (Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN) was reusable at least 4 times and gave moderate 2-BuOH yield (47%) in hydrogenolysis of 1,2-BuD. The promoting effect of Ru addition (0.5 wt%) to Ir-Fe/BN on hydrogenolysis of various alcohols was also confirmed. Combining catalytic tests with various characterizations, the promotion mechanism of Ru species in trimetallic catalysts was clarified. The Ru species in Ru(0.5)-Ir-Fe/BN form alloy with Ir and are enriched at the interface with BN surface, and direct interaction between Ru and Fe was not necessary in Ru-Ir-Fe alloy. The interface of Ir and Fe on the surface of Ir-Fe alloy may work as active sites for 1,2-diols to secondary alcohols via direct C−O hydrogenolysis, in which Ru-modified Ir activates H2 to form hydride-like species. The activity of Ru species in C−C bond cleavage was highly suppressed due to the direct interaction with Ir species and less exposed to substrate. Larger loading amount of Ru species (3 wt%) led to the formation Ru-rich trimetallic alloy, which further works as active sites for C−C bond scission.
